3.text:
Top 10 Facts About Australia
Welcome to Top10Archive! As we return to our

11.text:
trip around the globe, we’re stopping in
a rather revered country, one that many wished

17.text:
to see. As we digitally travel to The Land
Down Under, we're going to meet 300 jolly

22.text:
surfers, we'll see what mum has got cookin'
for all of your Wally siblings, we'll yabber

27.text:
about some Boomers, and we promise, there
isn't a Buckley's chance you'll be disappointed.

31.text:
This video, as Australians would call it,
is the Dinky-di.

34.text:
10. Australia’s Innovations
Many people likely don’t associate Australia

40.text:
with inventions – or really anything outside
of kangaroos – but the country has been

45.text:
home to some great innovators. Some of the
earliest inventors were Australia’s aboriginal

50.text:
population, who invented the boomerang some
ten thousand years ago. In the 20th century

56.text:
alone, Australian inventors were churning
out products that we still use on a regular

61.text:
basis today, such as notepads, configured
by stationer J. A. Birchall; Dr. David Warren’s

67.text:
black box flight recorder; and the power strip,
originally developed by Peter Talbot. Other

72.text:
notable firsts include the first feature-length
film, The Story of the Kelly Gang, the first

78.text:
refrigerator, and more locally used items
like the didgeridoo, a wooden musical instrument.

83.text:
For the girls watching this, you know those
Ugg boots you love so much? Yep, that's right,

88.text:
thank Australia the next time you slip them
on!

91.text:
9. Famous Australians
Sure, we all know Heath Ledger, Geoffrey Rush,

96.text:
Cate Blanchett, Paul Hogan, Nicole Kidman,
Hugh Jackman, and Mel Gibson as certified

101.text:
Australians, but there’s more that hails
from Down Under than great Hollywood talent.

106.text:
2000 Sydney Olympic winner Cathy Freeman,
who took gold in the 400m run, did her country

111.text:
proud, as did 1973 Nobel Prize winner Patrick
White. Radio's blast out tunes from the country’s

118.text:
musical stars, Keith Urban, Kylie Minogue,
and Olivia Newton John as our eyes are treated

124.text:
to works of art by artists such as Brett Whitely,
Pro Hart, and Normal Lindsay. Let’s also

130.text:
not forget the stunning personality of Steve
Irwin, who personified Australia for much

138.text:
Don’t let Outback Steakhouse fool you. Australian
cuisine is far more interesting than a blossoming

144.text:
tray of onions and steaks. In fact, for a
restaurant that prides itself on its Down

149.text:
Under style, it’s missing a well-known Australian
staple – Vegemite. Beyond the yeasty food

155.text:
paste, indigenous and more traditional Australians
are known to dine on the witchetty grub, a

161.text:
wood-eating larvae. Should an almond-tasting
insect not whet your appetite, maybe something

166.text:
sweeter like lamington or smokier like barbecued
snags will hit the spot. Those crazy Aussies

173.text:
are also known for their love for meat pies,
Macadamia nuts, Fantales, Tim Tams, Weet-Bix,

179.text:
and Anzac biscuits.
7. Tourist Attractions in Australia

184.text:
As you should and can expect with any country
you’ve yet to travel to, Australia is home

189.text:
to quite an array of attractions and sites
worth making the trip for. One of its more

194.text:
notable buildings is the Sydney Opera House,
a venue for concerts, local theater, and so

200.text:
much more. History buffs may enjoy visiting
the Shrine of Remembrance, which was built

205.text:
to commemorate and honor the 19,000 Victorians
that perished during the First World War.

211.text:
Thalassophobics are going to want to stray
from the Great Barrier Reef, but anyone with

216.text:
a keen interest in nature should get a kick
out of this system of 2,900 reefs and 900

221.text:
islands. Additional attractions include Port
Jackson, Blue Mountain, Tasmania, and the

231.text:
We may have seen some of Australia’s indigenous
wildlife tucked safely within some cave, but

236.text:
there’s nothing like seeing them in their
natural habitat. Critters like the Tasmanian

241.text:
Devil, a tiny creature Mel Blank turned into
a whirlwind of a beast, or the equally as

246.text:
cute wombat. We’d be doing a disservice
to not name the expected animals, like the

252.text:
kangaroo, koala, or baby-eating dingoe; but
we also don’t want to leave out the tiny

257.text:
kookaburra or the long-nosed fur seal, found
on the southern coast of Australia. There

263.text:
is, of course, the myriad of deadly creatures
like the cone snail, cassowary, stone fish,

268.text:
just to name a few. Oh, and how did we forget
the platypus, the beaver's ugly cousin. Or

274.text:
is the beaver the platypus' ugly cousin? Actually,
according to experts, they aren't related

280.text:
at all, as the platypus is only related to
one other animal in the rare monotreme family,

285.text:
the Echidna. So, yea.. that joke didn't go
as expected.

290.text:
5. Australian Gold Rush
The United States of America isn’t the only

296.text:
country to have experienced a gold rush. During
the 19th century, specifically in 1851, Edward

303.text:
Hargraves stumbled across a small speck of
gold near Bathurst. Post-discovery, Hargraves

308.text:
dubbed the gold site “Ophir,” was named
Commissioner of the Land, received a life

313.text:
pension, and inadvertently started a gold
rush in Australia. By 1852, 370,000 immigrants

321.text:
landed in Australia in hopes of cashing in
on the boom in mining. As it usually is when

326.text:
money is involved, tensions rose between the
miners and authorities over goldfield licensing,

332.text:
leading to 1,000 men proclaiming an oath at
the Eureka stockade to defend their rights

337.text:
and liberties. After intervention from Melbourne
troops, 22 of the 1,000 were killed and Eureka

347.text:
In 1856, the states of Victoria and South
Australia introduced a new system of voting

354.text:
that many countries still utilize today. Dubbed
the “Australian ballot,” and later the

359.text:
“secret ballot,” this voting method made
it possible for voters to be able to cast

364.text:
a ballot in privacy. As the protection of
voters became a growing concern across the

369.text:
globe, United States and parts of Europe adopted
the Aussie means of voting. Traditionally,

375.text:
the means of privacy is a ballot box or booth
of a specific dimension. The voters are given

380.text:
uniform cards and a uniform means of marking
said card. More modern voting methods have

385.text:
turned to electronic methods, which tend to
be under constant scrutiny… in the United

394.text:
Despite being seemingly in its own world,
the country of Australia and the people that

399.text:
devote themselves to it have experienced loss
during some of the world’s most trying times.

405.text:
To commemorate those that gave their lives
during the First World War, which is the first

409.text:
major military action fought by both Australian
and New Zealand forces, Aussie’s celebrate

414.text:
ANZAC day. ANZAC Day specifically points towards
the landing of Gallipoli on April 25th, 1915.

422.text:
During the battle on the peninsula, Australia
saw a loss of 8,000 soldiers against the Turkish

427.text:
defenders, who wound up pushing allied forces
into a defeat. For both Australia and New

433.text:
Zealand, the battle molded a legendary image
for the members of the Australian and New

442.text:
When it comes to World Records, Australia
isn't exempt from these feats, even when it

446.text:
comes to comedic value. In December of 2015,
some 320 Australians took to the waves, breaking

453.text:
the record for most "Surfing Santa's" at one
location. In November of 2015, David Richards

460.text:
broke a record for "Most bulbs on a Christmas
Tree" by stringing 518,838 LED lights on 22-meter

469.text:
or 72-foot tree in Canberra to raise money
for families affected by sudden infant death

475.text:
syndrome. On March 29th, 2008, daredevil Robbie
Maddison broke the record for the longest

481.text:
motorcycle ramp jump at 106.98 meters or roughly
351 feet at the Crusty Demons Night of World

490.text:
Records at Calder Park Raceway in Melbourne,
Victoria, Australia.

494.text:
1. The Island of Misfit Boys
When you don’t want someone in your presence,

500.text:
you find a way to banish them. In 1788, England
did exactly that by deporting approximately

507.text:
763 convicts to Australia, which was to act
as a prison colony. Over 50,000 criminals

514.text:
in 60 years were brought to the land Down
Under, but it was about more than rehabilitation.

519.text:
In fact, it was widely believed by England’s
upper class that criminals were defective,

526.text:
could not be rehabilitated, and simply needed
to be separated from those that lacked such

531.text:
defects. In this colony, prisoners were not
kept behind bars, but conditions were grim.

537.text:
Sadistic volunteers from Great Britain oversaw
prisoners, kept strict rules and harsh punishments.
